												NOTE: THIS GAME NO IS NO LONGER PLAYABLE, AS THE DEV HAS REMOVED ALL THE SERVERS.This is by no means the perfect game. There are flaws, there are bugs, I regularly get dropped by the server. There are trolls online, both intentionally trolling and unintentionally (if you don't know what offside is, read up on it before playing!) But what it does have going for it is sheer fun factor.If you remember Sensible Soccer, WoSO is in a similar vein, from the pixel graphics to sharing more than a little in common with Sensible World of Soccer's name. But as the telling difference in the name reveals, WoSO is an online game. You control just one player, with the other players on your team controlled by other humans (yay) or the AI (boo). And it's this multiplayer element that is at the heart of WoS's fun factor. As in real life football, playing as a team is essential; good positioning is worth a lot and a team playing as a unit can still beat a team full of better players who are all playing for themselves. It can be really satisfying when your team puts together a string of neat passes culminating in a goal, or when you've spent 90 minutes defending resolutely only to nick a 1-0 victory in the dying moments on the counter.Controls are relatively simple; movement is via mouse (run to the cursor a la diablo), gamepad or keyboard (not a good option IMO). I'm using a controller where you have 3 buttons that I'd call "shoot" "lob" and "pass". The controls are not well explained, although there is a tutorial that gives you the basics. Bascially "lob" is a high ball, "pass" is a low ball and "shoot" increases in height with power. Hold down the button to power up. You can also control the height of the ball by either moving the mouse cursor nearer or further from your player, or moving your joystick in a similar fashion. "lob" performs a slide tackle when defending. Headers are finicky at first, but basically involve either the "pass" or "shoot" buttons ("lob" will make you slide instead).There are no fouls - strategically taking out opponents is part of the game and underlines the arcade feel of the game. Offsides are implemented, so no goal hanging allowed. Other than that there are 3 player models (small/normal/large) you can choose from if you pay for a VIP account. The small players are however vastly overpowered (they are quicker than everyone else) and I personally find it gets boring quickly if one team has several fast players and the other doesn't; you can essentially run the entire length of the pitch with the ball without being caught, which removes any element of tactics from the game. I think there needs to be a better model for financing the servers than one that makes the game less fun (IMO of course) for everyone.Other downsides include: No ability to kick players. AFK players can ruin matches by playing everyone onside and making teams unbalanced. The same player may be AFK for over half an hour and isn't kicked. As with any online game, there are trolls. But most players are very friendly. If you have the bad luck of joining a server full of 13 year olds, best to switch to another server. As per usual, things get better later at night when the kids are in bed. No real auto-balancing of training matches. While the game assigns new players who join the server to the team with less players, an auto-balancing feature would be nice - at the very least at the start of each match, if not each half. Unbalanced matches are no fun. A lot of players will however change teams to balance things out. A match-making mode is supposedly on the way, which should help in this regard. A few weird bugs/idiosyncracies lead to WTF moments every now and then. Nothing to ruin the game though. The league and team systems don't work. The leagues are full of dead teams and playing matches between teams is a pain, especially as it's uncommon for 6 players in the same team to be online at the same time. I much prefer 6v6 (the maximum), so I spend almost all my time playing training matches. I find 1v1 and 2v2 matches fun for a few minutes, but not for a whole match. There are a number of exploits in the game. Some are obvious exploits, some are at the very least gamey. You don't have to take advantage of them of course. The dev does respond to requests and suggestions, and there have been several changes made to the game since release - many good, some bad, and some neither here nor there. However, active development and a willingness to engage with players is always a good thing.Seeing as WoSO is free, there's no reason not to try it our if you like football games - especially if you were a Sensi fan back in the day. This isn't a game for the people who buy FIFA or PES for the skill moves and motion capture graphics. WoSO is much more tactical - yet also more arcadey- than those 2, by virtue of its simple nature. If you do try it out, definitely play the tutorial and practice knocking the ball about a bit. Play a couple of matches on an empty server both with and without bots to practice passing and shooting. It only takes a short while to master the basic controls. It'll take you a long time to master the game though.

												World of Soccer, the successor to Netsoccer and Netsoccer 2, brings you an unmatched experience in virtual football. It allows you to play the sport we all love in a way that most games do not let you. It removes the arcadey experience of "Be a Pro" modes in larger games and gives you full control over your player's actions. Like the best games, it's easy to learn and hard to master. It will take some time for you to learn the intricacies of the game, but when you do, and you actually find a team and "click" with them, it makes for one of the most satisfying gaming experiences you'll ever know. The controls might not be the most obvious for people who haven't played it before, but you can quickly learn what is possible and then, practice makes perfect.Having played its predecessor since 2006, and having spent an embarassing amount of hours on it, I can only recommend to you from experience that it's something you should try if you feel like playing football with your friends and make sick plays, but don't feel like getting kicked in the shins.The game itself does feel like it's not yet completely functional, some things aren't very intuitive (like chat) and it can definitely become a lot better, but I still recommend you try it.

												Playing this game is like playing an unfinished product. Mainly because it is one. With my experience, the gameplay is the same - either too balanced, or too unbalanced. What do I mean? Well, this game would have been tons more fun if you could upgrade your player to specific stats, so training rooms and teams could require a specific level cap (so it isn't too unbalanced).This would create strategy (that is missing from the game) and complexity, trying out new styles and possibly being a fun experience. However, we settle for this - a really basic unfinished product where every character plays the exact same. When in matches, unless you're teamed up with people who aren't selfish ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, you'll find that the only person defending is your keeper (who is CPU controlled), every teammate ever would just act like a hero and come up forth, ignoring basic offside rules, ultimately screwing up the team. This could be countered by adding a ratings system based on the player's performance in his positon, so these ratings stick to a player after each game so people could know how much of a ♥♥♥♥ he is. But I'm not here trying to convince the devs to put a little bit more balance (or fun complex unbalance) to the game even though it would be great. I'm here to advise you whether this game is worth it or not. In conclusion, this game is an unsuccessful attempt at a minimum viable product, every player plays the same, basic physics and rules aren't that well implemented, slide tackles are too op (since there isn't any fouls) so you find everybody just lunging at each other at the speed of light, and the whole experience is just the same every time. This game neither showcases the random exciting nature of the real sport, nor does it showcase the players' skills. And that would be a good thing, if the game was just a simple fun experience, but it definitely isn't one. I'd advise the devs to take what they've learned from this failed attempt and focus on improving on the core formula, since this could be a great title, until then - I wouldn't recommend this title.

												Overall Review: 7.5/10OverviewThis game is great. The servers have a bad history, but after a bit the creators got new servers up and running and logins are working flawlessly. The person making this game is a previous developer of Net Soccer, and it shows. The UI is the most painful thing in this game, expecially when it was back when the servers were trashy, but since the game just went up from greenlight it's okay to have some inconvience riddled inside.GameplayThe controls are, if not exactly a replica of, a close copy of Net Soccer, which controls very well. I like the ball lob mechanic the most, and the slide tackle works very well. I've never played Outdoor Soccer(Football), but these seem very nice for the game. The AI controlled players are very well created too, I'm honestly suprised at how well they preform. You can call to them to pass the ball to you, but I wish it made some notification so that you could notify other players as well.Community & Online PlayThe community isn't that great according to some people, but I haven't seen one person that is too rude or plain annoying yet. The team system is well made too, You can make your own custom jerseys, which look actually nice in game. The organised matches are the bread and butter of this game and I love to play in them. With good communication you can make great plays and tactics, and its overall very well done.ConclusionOverall I think this game could DEFINITELY use some changes over time, but for only 3 days on steam, it looks amazing and plays very well. This opens up interesting decisions; should you play attack or defence, or adapt as the game flows?It'd be good if they added an offline mode with switchable players like the original "Sensi" just for fun and practice. It'd be even better if we could have local 2-4 player games in that mode as well.I've also seen a few complaints about the UI. I've seen better certainly, but it does what it needs to do and I didn't feel it detracted from the experience.Overall, it's a great free game that's fun and hardly takes up any space.
